Until Bush is OUT OF OFFICE....

and I can't believe that  former President George H. W. Bush (the soon-to-be ex president's father) is already backing his other son, Jeb Bush, to be president someday.  Like we need yet another eight years of the same politics!  I think the American people know better as proven by the election of Obama.  We want CHANGE and we want it now, dernit!

So now it's just 14 days until the current George W. Bush is out of office!

I went the whole day without realizing it was Father's Day today.  Every other year, I've had a breakdown around this time and/or around April 5th, my father's birthday.  The reason is that there's a aniversery effect even years later after a loved one passes on, and especially in my dad's case, because he was such a pivotal figure in my life. 

I might regret slightly not going to church this week, but he didn't like my church anyway.  He thought it wasn't a real religion since we had no core beliefs.  That's just as well. 

I just started thinking about him randomly a few minutes ago, like I often do, even without remembering it was Father's Day.  One MySpace bulletin reminded me, and then I realized I thought of him right at the right time.  I do it anyway so it's not like it's fortuitous, but it's good to remember.

I want to be a better person so that just in case Heaven really is a place and not a state of mind, I can go there and see him again.  He's always there anyway because I dream of him often.  He always tells me he's still alive but I'm the only one who can see him.  He is still alive and helping me and leading me to do good things.  Even when I do bad things, he doesn't get as angry as he did in life.  He had a very harsh temper, and there was no crossing him when he had his mind set to something.  Most of my mother's family could not get along with him, and so we were alienated from them during his life.  I visited my cousins occasionally, and I saw my grandfather once in a blue moon, but not too often considering we only lived three hours away.  Life happens that way, and there's no stopping it, I suppose. 

Time does not heal all wounds, but all wounds don't need to be healed.

[edit] Here's a link to a website devoted to celebrating holidays one day at a time, today featuring Father's Day.

wow, man, that last entry was a dense little paragraph all on cleaning.  

Okay, so the other thing is.......oh I can't remember. Poot.  Sleepformethen. Goodnight.

About half or two-fifths or so of my cleaning was done(by me).  Now, tomorrow morning (whenever my body decides that is), I'm bringing books I don't need down to the garage to keep until I move.  Next, I'm putting the laundry I left in the laundryroom (against the rules, but no one follows 'em) in the machine before anyone else gets a chance to steal it.  Next, I'm taking a shower while that goes, then getting dressed and starting the dryer and the next load (hoping no one has stolen it yet, and I've got quarters).  Then finish dishes, then dry and put them away, collect any loose paperwork, put excess boxes somewhere discrete, make a finale onceove of my bedroom floor before emptying out the dust from the vacuum and vacuuming everything.  Finally, I'll give the bathroom the most thorough cleaning it's had since I've been there, also picking up all the stuff from the counter around the sink.  lalala, yeah, I don't really have a choice about it, you realize.  Of course, I get a deduction on anything I'd have to pay in deposit based on having lived here a year, but I want to make sure that deduction is subtracted from the smallest possible amount (hopefully zero, in which case it's a moot point).

Someone told me to start making lists of things to do and then do them all without hesitation.  That would make my life easier, less thinking about all the things hanging over my head.

So here's a simple list:

Cleaning my house.

1. Put all dirty clothes in one or more hampers/bags.  Set in one spot together until laundry machines are vacant for my own use.
2. Do the dishes.
3. Clean the counters.
4. Sweep the floor.
5. Mop the floor.
6. Take out the trash.
7. Take out any recycling.
8. Empy the vacuum.
9. Vacuum the bedroom and livingroom rugs.
10. Clean the bathroom.

I'll see how far I get before I get lazy (or don't).

Wow man.

here are a few (real) scenarios.....


1. I have a boyfriend in New York whom I never see.  He may move out here soon, for real, and then it would be a more real life relationship.  Time will only tell.  

What I need advice with is the extent I should be wrapped up in things with him.  Right now, I even have my cell phone attached to his.  We have separate minutes but are connected.  It's a bit weird.  In any event, I feel like we've crossed some lines most people would recognize from a casual relationship to seriousness although we've only been around each other in person once.  

I have known him for five years, going on six.... 

I know the decision is my own, but I want an outiside opinion to know if what I'm doing is crazy....

2. How can I stop self destructive behavior, namely binging and sleeping all day and crap like that?  I hate myself when I do it and love myself when I don't, yet I do it anyway..  Why?!

3.  How come I keep making resolutions to change my life but never DO IT??
I hate when I do it.  So why do I?

I went to Jazz Conditioning this morning, and in a little bit, I'm leaving to go to Jazz and Hip Hop dance.  I'm also going to go back to MPC at around 9am and go swimming for the first time in a while.  I'll commit myself to doing a few laps at first, maybe between 5 and 10.  Maybe I'll stick with two main strokes, like back and freestyle and then also paddleboard kicking.  I hope to increase the laps every time I go.

My apartment inspection is next week.  When I get home tonight and also tomorrow after swimming, I'm going to get busy with the cleaning again.  I have lots and lots of boxes now, probably more than I need, so I'll get crackalackin.

:-)

I've been writing loads of poetry.  I've also been getting ready to leave in a month.  I'm going to Marina to "structured living".  It's a bit unorthodox of a plan, but so be it.  I've always been unorthodox since I was a kid.  I was told I would crawl backwards.  I came out of my mother feet first.  I was nearly dead although I was not premature.  They said that I had an apgar (measurement they do with newborns) score of one.  That means I was barely alive.  Yet I survived.

Later in my life I would keep getting injured.  I got a large door slammed against my head, but I was fine.  I barely cried.  I barely cried according to my parents except just to communicate.  They tried to give me soy or rice milk at one point, but I didn't take to that until I was already weaned.  Besides, I weaned much later than most children.

I won't go on and embarrass myself pointing out my strangeness.  Let's just say there's been probably no single event in my life that occurred the same way as everyone else experiences it.  I don't suppose that will ever change.

May 31, 2007

 

 

Ms. Wilma [last name]

[address deleted for safety]

Dear Wilma:

 

Like you, I am deeply disappointed the President refused to modify his position on the Iraq war, despite the fact that Americans overwhelming oppose his "stay the course" position. I could not give him a blank check to continue the war in Iraq, so I voted 'no' and opposed the war funding supplemental, which sadly passed by a vote of 280-142 (Roll Call 425).

 

There is no doubt that Iraq has fallen into a civil war, and despite the best efforts of our men and women in uniform, there is no military solution to the current conflict. The solution in Iraq is political, not military, yet the Administration has refused to negotiate with Congress on any benchmarks or timelines that would have put political pressure on the Iraqi government to take concrete steps towards peace. I am offended by the Administration's recent statement: "If we let up, we'll be attacked." Our troops have already been attacked and are being killed in Iraq everyday. Tragically, the death toll for US soldiers now stands at 3,434, and President Bush has warned the American people to expect a bloody summer. I strongly believe that America needs to defend herself from a future attack. But the invasion of Iraq and the subsequent occupation has, according to the Administration's own National Intelligence Estimate, created more terrorists and more anti-American sentiment than before September 11.

 

When the Defense Department Authorization (HR 2237) was debated recently, I supported an amendment that would have started the drawdown of US troops in Iraq. Unfortunately, the amendment failed by a vote of 255 to 171 (Roll Call 330).

 

Despite the House Leadership's best efforts to end the war, the bottom line is that governance requires responsibility, and the House of Representatives acted responsibly to fund the troops. President Bush may have won some breathing room until September when military commanders can assess the results of the surge strategy, but you can be assured that the Democratic Majority will continue to support the American people in their opposition to the war. Please be assured that I will continue to fight to bring our troops home as quickly and safely as possible.

 

Sincerely,

 

SAM FARR

Member of Congress

 

 

Please be sure to visit my website at www.farr.house.gov

I'm just crowned tonight
I can't believe I've begun
Fight through the evernight
I've gone above and beyond
I'm seen the road at every bend
I'm walking down the line
I'm feeling quite sublime

This whole road is so surreal
My turning feet go straight but wrong
Spinning in straight lines
Oxymoronic.

Father, father
Burning bright
In the shadow of the night

Father, father
Can you hear
Every question
Every fear?

Father, father
Can you breathe
While you're drowning 
in this sea?

Father, father
Can you call
And brush away
The road for all?

Father, father
Never fear
Never wonder
Never cry

Don't wish today
Don't wish tomorrow
Were any different
Than yesterday

I always dream about him, even to this day.  It has been at least four, maybe five years since his demise, and it is still as fresh in my memory as the day it happened.  For a long while, my memory had dismissed all events prior to his death.  I believe I walled it all off to avoid the pain of the many times that I fell crying while my parents fought.  I had no room of my own, so I witnessed it all, and eventually I ended up counseling them with the very tools that my father had invented in his own philosophy, which he dubbed with the title of Modern Aspectivism.

In my dream, he had very long hair, past his waste.  He had the same beard that he had in real life but longer as well.  Later, he appeared to have shaved clean, cut his hair and donned a suit and tie.  The only strange thing was that his tie was on backwards and hung from his back.  I never once saw my father when he was clean shaven.  All my life he had his beard, so this dream seems a bit peculiar.

In all of my dreams about my father, he appears to be alive as he ever was and saying that either he is still alive and everyone else but me doesn't  know it or that he is alive and will appear although everyone believes he is dead.  Either is a second coming of sorts or he just feigned death to get people's attention.

Of course, I know for a fact that he did die.  I saw his dead corpse myself that night, and it was white as a ghost.  They had not put the sheet over him then, and it was the scariest, saddest thing I had ever witnessed.  That night I didn't cry, and I don't believe I have ever outright cried over his death.  I was partially in shock and partially heavily medicated.  I exclaimed monotonously, "Dead dad, dead dad, dead dad."  I was also angry at him for leaving me when I had just left the hospital, the very one that I had to visit when he died.  He hated hospitals, and it is a shame that he had to die in one, because according to my mother, he may not have been completely dead when she found him on the floor.

I cannot imagine how my mother can live in that house with the memory of where he died haunting her night and day.  He died where my own bed used to be, and whenever I sit on the couch that now occupies that space, I cannot help but think about it.  That was also where my bed was, and sometimes when I used to have trouble sleeping, I would go there.  It was comforting somehow.

Maybe it has something to do with Father's Day rolling around again.  You would think I might have gotten over all of that, but no, I suppose I never truly will.

I guess I have this bad habit of once I get some kind of momentum going or even change courses in a new direction, I feel like I want to dive right in and conquer the world all in one day.  I want to find out everything there is to know about whatever it is and become an expert and then grab onto it and turn it into my life's work even if it's something I've only just discovered.  I think there's a very strong part of me that wants to have a definite purpose in life.  Apparently, it doesn't exactly matter what that purpose is.  I think that throughout most of my life, in fact, I have been very driven in whatever my passion of the moment happened to be.  In high school, I was passionate about a few things -- veganism was a definite must.  I can't honestly count how many speeches, papers or other projects I must have done explaining the benefits of veganism and the downfalls of not being so.  Along with that, I was an avid member of our little environmental club -- S.M.A.R.T (Students Making A Right Tomorrow).  We were this little group of hippie kids who took it upon ourselves to do all the school's recycling (whenever we got around to it) and organizing various ways to support whatever environmental causes we could with our limited resources.  I wish we would have made a bigger impact because it's becoming more and more apparent that this world's environmental situation is pretty close to irreparable.  In that department, I feel like people are only just now starting to wake up and it's kind of a too little, too late scenario.  Anyway, I digress.  As I went along, I always found new things to be passionate about.  They did always seem to have some coming underlying theme.  They always seemed to support some cause, some underrepresented minority of people or undersupported social cause or something where the recipient of my efforts would do some kind of good to the world or to some group of vulnerable people.  I guess maybe I have some kind of savior complex.  I only feel worthwhile if I'm out there saving the world in some small way.  Maybe it's my way of making myself feel important.  I don't know.

I was late to my appointment at 3:00 yesterday and then totally missed the one at 5:30 because although I sat waiting at the bus stop, it did not come with enough time to get there.  When it finally got there, I made an attempt to get there within reasonable time although still late.  When I got to the Edgewater Transit Exchange in Sand City, I got on the 16 bus that was supposed to go Fort Ord and then Marina.  This particular route was not going that direction until after going back to Monterey.  I got on there anyway feeling thoroughly frustrated and when I got back to the Monterey Transit Plaza, I just got on the number 10 bus that stops right outside my house.  I forgot about that last appointment and decided to reschedule because there was no way I was going to be on time.  Oh well.

Today I went up to campus after finding that I was once again out of money and slightly overdrawn. I'm not out of food or anything, but I need to figure out I'm going to get around.  Today I got money from people around, and that worked but I'm not sure I can do that every time.  Someone still owes me some money and I'm not sure they were ever intended to repay me but I sent them a message asking for at least a little.  Just ten or 20 would be enough to tide me over.  Oh well.  I'll survive.  I'll just get a couple dollars from a neighbor maybe.  I'll survive.  I always have.

I went to see my pdoc about a half hour ago. I'm still out but at the Plumes coffee house downtown.  We were trying to decide if I should stay on my current regime of Seroquel and Lamictal and the pros and cons.  The nurse practitioner that I saw said that the reason they don't want to switch me back to the Abilify or Geodon is that the side effects are too difficult to work with.  Abilify causes akisthesia, which is an involuntary movement and twitching that is very annoying.  Actually, both of those drugs cause that side effect.  The Geodon also disrupted my sleep pattern to the point that in one situation, I actually fell asleep when I got to my placement at Monarch Charter Elementary (in Santa Cruz) one day.  They thought I was on illicit drugs, and I messed up by telling them my diagnosis, which was incorrect then and much more scary.  Bad times.  Bad, bad, bad.

Okay, I must go before I'm late.  

I'll be back after this and probably after I have my appointment with Dr. Irene this evening at 5:30. 

Ta ta.

I keep sleeping too late. This morning I was supposed to get up, call my insurance and make my payment and then go to my appointment. None of this happened except the getting up part, which did not occur exactly at the scheduled time. Bah humbug. Now I've been rescheduled for 3:00 for that appointment, and I have another one at 1:30 and then one on campus at 5:30. Jimeny cricket! I won't even have time to go get my papers signed for dropping the one class. Bah humbug again. In order to cheer myself up, I'm going to post one fractal I happen to love ...and also some footprints ...and finally, one nice picture of a candle.

For some reason, I am emensely tired.  I ought to take my meds this instant and be off to dream wonderful dreams that I know I'll never remember because I never remember any dreams.  Le sigh.

Oh well.  Now I have that Faith No More song from my playlist stuck in my head 'cause I played it over and over again as I was concentrating on other things really.  I'm told subliminal messages are more impressionable.  Whatever.

Okay.  Good afternoon, good evening, and good night.

I thoroughly intended to do homework, but then I didn't have the answers.  Now, I guess this evening I'll make a good stab at the three lesson plans.  I have one full one, one that is three-fourths finished and one that is only about a third finished.  It's not all bad.  Finally, I'll scrape together anything I have of the case study I already turned in and see if I can make something of that.

yay.

I was looking up song lyrics and then I did a general Google search for David Wilcox, a singer-songwriter that I just started to like.  Turns out he is playing at the Kwumba Jazz Center in Santa Cruz.  If I could find a way to get there (maybe ask Noel or someone else if they're interested), that would be awesome!  I've only been to Kwumba once when I was taking my Jazz History class at UCSC.  Maybe Sierra or Kenji would be interested even though I know both of them are more into rap and stuff.  Sierra once invited me to a bluegrass concert, though, but then she had to go somewhere and it didn't happen.  Maybe she is into other stuff too.  It's worth a try.  The show is on May 5th, Cinco de Mayo.  Could be fun.

Okay, for real.  Time to finish the last few questions and get to those lesson plans.  No one's gonna do it for me, ya know.

[Edit - 2:22 pm - Due to insufficient info]

    While trying to complete the last of my final exam (which is take-home and open book/open note), I discovered that I don't have the notes or Powerpoint presentation covering the last three concepts of proactive, educative and functional strategies.  I vaguely remember them but not exactly and want to make sure I do the best I can.  Each one is worth two points, so that's six total, which could definitely make the difference between one or two grades.  I e-mailed my professor to see if I should just take an educated stab at the answers or what.  Sometimes I think this program I'm in is just too too easy.  I never had a situation like this where basically all of my quizzes and exams are open book and open note and not even very hard to start with.  Perhaps the fact that it's so simple and also not about very complex concepts but rather more of a how-to guide -- perhaps that makes this schooling experience less challenging and hence less engaging.  I'm so used to everything being theoretical, grounded in nothing but heady thought provoking stuff that this more practical and less challenging material might just lull me into a sense of not having to try my best.  I'll have to get over that right away.  I suppose the material is simple for the fact that we are also expected to work basically full time -- at least some of us who have internships or others who have jobs besides this.  Oh well.  Every experience is a new experience, and sometime this will no longer be new and I'll have got the hang of it.  Maybe by then it'll be over but by then teaching won't be new either, and I hope I'll have got the hang of that even more so.

Love
John Lennon

Love is real, real is love
Love is feeling, feeling love
Love is wanting to be loved

Love is touch, touch is love
Love is reaching, reaching love
Love is asking to be loved

Love is you
You and me
Love is knowing
We can be

Love is free, free is love
Love is living, living love
Love is needing to be loved

Your spell that mistifies everything I know about myself
tends to pull the strands of my heart ever closer
to the brink of madness and
self destruction.

Your bending maze befits the emotion 
overcoming my senses and dragging me 'round
endlessly taunting, dragging me on
down the darkest road yet to be found.

Your guileless selfishness teaches me how
self preservation must begin right now,
for I can't live without you
yet I can't live with me
forgetting about all that I ever could be.

Your pitiful pretense of caring compassion
fades in the shadows that used to cover your intentions
so that beyond a doubt, I know the sound
of facing the truth when you're not around.

Yes.  It's that time.  Time for work and time for none.  Time to type and time to sleep.  Time to accomplish and time to relinquish.  Time to try and time to fail.  It's homework time and that means -- procrastination.

I started reading The Hobbit once again last night around 2:00 am.  I woke up in the middle of the night, made myself another helping of deep fried tofu (so good yet so bad!) as a midnight snack and began reading The Hobbit.

Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Blunt the knives and bend the forks!
That's what Bilbo Baggins hates --
Smash the bottles and burn the corks!

Cut the cloth and tread on the fat!
Pour milk on the pantry floor!
Leave the bones on the bedroom mat!
Splash the wine on every door!

Dump the crocks in a boiling bowl;
Pound them up with a thumping pole;
And when you've finished, if any are whole;
Send them down the hall to roll!

That's what Bilbo Baggins hates!
So, carefully! carefully with the plates!

Fun stuff.  J.R.R. Tolkien wrote this book as an amusement for his own children and then it became a big hit.  He originally wrote The Silmarillion that did not get published until after his demise.  I'm planning now to read The Hobbit and then all three of The Lord of the Rings and then The Silmarillion and finally finish the only books I haven't read yet -- The History of Middle Earth, The Lost Tales and The Unfinished Tales.  By then, I should be almost a Tolkien expert although not quite as impressive as those I've found who actually understand some of the Elvish languages invented by Tolkien.  Of course, being that Tolkien was a linguist, these are possibly the most profound and important parts of the whole thing.

Right now, however, before I get to such fun and interesting things, I must prevail.  I must prevail over my p- p- p- procrastination and in the end live to fight another day! Muahahaha!

Once upon an era not too long ago, this little (big) girl used to update her journal at least maybe three times a day. Le sigh.

Today, I'm starting a new era (hopefully).  I'm starting a new set of goals for combatting my weight loss struggle that has plagued me ever since I began these "mood stabilizing" medications which work so far as stabilizing my mood but also have served to about double my pants size in the last four years that I have been on them!  I'm not exaggerating either. 

I feel like I've tried enough weight loss gimicks -- Weight Watchers, LA Weight Loss, Eat to Live (not so much a gimick, but a plan nontheless)... and now I'm just going to do it the tried-and-true way (well, by others, not by me).  That is -- diet and exercise...

I've decided I'm going to give up using public transit so much (now that I'm no longer driving, it gives me less excuse to be lazy) and use my bike that I paid a pretty penny for when I want to go somewhere.  I don't think it's too far to get to school (even though I may not be in school that much longer -- details later) or to go into Monterey.  I just have to time it right.  That's why tomorrow morning I'm getting up bright and early and biking into Monterey along Del Monte Ave. and exploring all the different locations I can get to from there.  First, I'm going to try getting up to my therapist's office on Munras, which is an uphill ride, so I may end up walking some of it if it gets too steep.  As I get better, I suppose that can be a challenge for myself, seeing how far I can go uphill in various places. 

I might also try enjoying myself along the coast around the Fisherman's Wharf area.  I used to bike there all the time when I lived next to El Estero Park.   That was in the beginning of this "mental health rollercoaster" as I so frequently call it.  Now I'm four years down the track, and I'm hoping to get up to snuff physically for all the good that I've accomplished mentally.

In place of my fears
my heart fills with tears
Through the sadness and the madness
my anger quietly cheers
while the masses murmer sweetly
all the troubles that have been brought
and the rivers wander wildy
though they've never had to be taught

Why can I never see
what never happened to me?
Why can I never feel
the reason that you are real?
Why can I not believe
everything I see in front of me?

What's wrong with love today?
When did we go astray?

I miss the wondering of a child.
I miss the misty mountains wild.
I miss the caring not the staring 
when we used to be so daring.

I wonder else I have missed.
Who was it that you kissed?
Why can't I hear the sound
of a hundred years around
in which we've never met
something we won't regret
and never ever forget
to appreciate the rest?

I always write these weird-ass poems that sound all smooth and meaningful, but they really mean nothing.

I'm feeling okay.  I didn't let anyone know that I actually ate some cheese on my eggplant sandwich.  I was dooped.  That's okay.  They need not know.

I didn't have any dessert, though, and that's why I had wanted to go to Tillie Gort's which caters to vegetarians better.  But no one listens to me.  That's okay.
